conclusion: Setup with four liquid sources at the top, colored baffles in the middle, and two collection containers at the bottom.
Liquid A falls straight down from the orange source.
There are no baffles directly in the path of liquid A.
Liquid A would reach the red container labeled E.
Liquid B falls straight down from the white/light gray source.
Liquid B might hit the edge of the pink baffle but would mostly continue downward.
Liquid B would hit the red structure at the bottom.
Liquid B would be directed to container E following the shape of the red structure.
Liquid C falls from the blue source.
Liquid C would hit the pink baffle first, deflecting it downward at an angle.
Liquid C would likely hit the white baffle after deflection.
The white baffle would deflect liquid C toward the right side.
Liquid C would ultimately flow into container F.
Liquid D falls from the yellow source on the right.
Liquid D might hit the green baffle or pass to its right.
If liquid D passes to the right of the green baffle, it would hit the white baffle.
The white baffle would direct liquid D toward container F.
Even if some liquid D hits the green baffle first, the flow would still be directed toward container F.
Liquids A and B will flow into container E; liquids C and D will flow into container F.
The central baffles play crucial roles in directing liquids C and D toward container F.
